words.meaning: The quality of being dedicated or committed to a task or purpose.
examples: Her dedication to her students was an inspiration.
It takes a lot of dedication to become a professional athlete.

words.meaning: To regard or consider in a specified way.
examples: The court will deem the contract to be valid.
She deemed it appropriate to wear a formal dress to the event.

words.meaning: To spoil the surface or appearance of (something), e.g., by drawing or writing on it.
examples: The vandals defaced the public monument with graffiti.
He was fined for defacing a library book.

words.meaning: (Of a remark, writing, etc.) damaging the good reputation of someone; slanderous or libelous.
examples: He sued the newspaper for publishing a defamatory article about him.
She claimed the comments were defamatory and harmed her career.

words.meaning: To damage the good reputation of (someone); slander or libel.
examples: The politician claimed his opponent was trying to defame him with false accusations.
It is illegal to defame someone's character.

words.meaning: Failure to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or appear in a court of law.
examples: He defaulted on his car loan payments.
If you default on the agreement, you will lose your deposit.

words.meaning: To put off (an action or event) to a later time; postpone.
examples: The committee decided to defer the decision until the next meeting.
He deferred his college admission for a year to travel.

words.meaning: Humble submission and respect.
examples: He treated his elders with great deference.
In deference to her wishes, we did not discuss the sensitive topic.

words.meaning: Showing deference; respectful.
examples: The young man had a deferential attitude towards his superiors.
She spoke in a deferential tone to the judge.

words.meaning: Open resistance; bold disobedience.
examples: She acted in defiance of her parents' wishes.
The protest was an act of defiance against the new law.

words.meaning: Showing defiance.
examples: The defiant student refused to apologize for her behavior.
He had a defiant look in his eyes.

words.meaning: To cause (something) to change direction by interposing something; to cause (someone) to deviate from an intended purpose.
examples: The goalie deflected the shot with his hand.
She tried to deflect the criticism by changing the subject.

words.meaning: To provide money to pay (a cost or expense).
examples: The company offered to defray the costs of the employee's training.
A scholarship helped to defray the expenses of his education.

words.meaning: Neatly skillful and quick in one's movements.
examples: The artist made deft strokes with her brush.
He has a deft touch for handling delicate negotiations.

words.meaning: Skillful performance or ability without difficulty.
examples: She admired the deftness with which the chef chopped the vegetables.
The pianist played the complex piece with incredible deftness.

words.meaning: No longer existing or functioning.
examples: The old railroad line is now defunct.
He worked for a now-defunct software company.

words.meaning: To decline or deteriorate physically, mentally, or morally.
examples: The peaceful protest began to degenerate into violence.
His health has degenerated over the years.

words.meaning: To treat or regard (someone) with contempt or disrespect.
examples: He would never degrade himself by begging for money.
The harsh working conditions degraded the employees.

words.meaning: To worship, regard, or treat (someone or something) as a god.
examples: Ancient Roman emperors were often deified after their death.
Fans tend to deify their favorite celebrities.

words.meaning: To do something that one considers to be beneath one's dignity.
examples: The queen did not deign to answer the reporter's impertinent question.
He would not deign to speak to his former friends.

words.meaning: (Of food or drink) delicious.
examples: The restaurant served a variety of delectable desserts.
She prepared a delectable meal for her guests.

words.meaning: To entrust (a task or responsibility) to another person, typically one who is less senior than oneself.
examples: A good manager knows when to delegate tasks to their team.
She delegated the responsibility of booking the flights to her assistant.

words.meaning: Causing harm or damage.
examples: Smoking has a deleterious effect on your health.
The chemical is deleterious to the environment.

words.meaning: Done consciously and intentionally.
examples: It was a deliberate act of vandalism.
She made a deliberate effort to be friendly to everyone.

words.meaning: To determine the limits or boundaries of.
examples: The treaty was intended to delimit the borders between the two countries.
It is important to delimit the scope of the research project.

words.meaning: To describe or portray (something) precisely.
examples: The report clearly delineates the company's new strategy.
The artist's sketch delineated the features of the landscape.

words.meaning: The action of describing or portraying something precisely.
examples: The book provides a clear delineation of the historical events.
The delineation of the characters in the novel was excellent.

words.meaning: To impose a misleading belief upon (someone); deceive; fool.
examples: Don't delude yourself into thinking that he will change.
The con artist managed to delude his victims into giving him their money.

words.meaning: A severe flood; a great quantity of something arriving at the same time.
examples: The town was hit by a deluge that caused widespread flooding.
The office received a deluge of complaints after the new policy was announced.

words.meaning: An idiosyncratic belief or impression that is firmly maintained despite being contradicted by what is generally accepted as reality or rational argument.
examples: He was suffering from the delusion that he was a famous rock star.
She was under the delusion that she could pass the exam without studying.

words.meaning: To reach inside a receptacle and search for something; to research or make painstaking inquiries into something.
examples: She delved into her handbag to find her keys.
The book delves into the history of the ancient civilization.

words.meaning: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices rather than by using rational argument.
examples: The politician was a demagogue who used fear to gain votes.
The country was led astray by a charismatic demagogue.

words.meaning: To set the boundaries or limits of.
examples: A fence was built to demarcate the property line.
It is difficult to demarcate the line between friendship and love.

words.meaning: To cause a severe loss in the dignity of and respect for (someone or something).
examples: He would never demean himself by accepting a bribe.
The purpose of the hazing ritual was to demean the new recruits.

words.meaning: Outward behavior or bearing.
examples: She has a calm and professional demeanor.
His cheerful demeanor hid his inner sadness.

words.meaning: Relating to the structure of populations.
examples: The study collected demographic information such as age, gender, and income.
The product is targeted at a young demographic.

words.meaning: (Of a person) tending to show feelings, especially of affection, openly.
examples: He is a very demonstrative person who is not afraid to hug his friends.
She was not a demonstrative child, but she loved her parents deeply.

words.meaning: To give (someone) a lower rank or less senior position, usually as a punishment.
examples: He was demoted from manager to assistant for his poor performance.
The officer was demoted for insubordination.

words.meaning: Denoting or relating to language used by ordinary people; popular or colloquial.
examples: The novel was praised for its use of demotic language.
He preferred demotic speech to the formal language of academia.

words.meaning: To raise doubts or objections or show reluctance.
examples: She demurred at the suggestion that she should work on the weekend.
He did not demur when asked to take on the extra responsibility.

words.meaning: (Of a woman or her behavior) reserved, modest, and shy.
examples: She was a demure young woman who rarely spoke.
He was attracted to her demure and gentle nature.

words.meaning: To criticize unfairly; disparage.
examples: He would often denigrate the work of his colleagues.
It is wrong to denigrate someone just because you disagree with them.

words.meaning: Past tense of denigrate; criticized unfairly.
examples: The artist's work was denigrated by the critics.
She felt her contributions to the project were being denigrated.

words.meaning: An inhabitant or occupant of a particular place.
examples: The squirrel is a common denizen of our city parks.
The old bar was a favorite haunt of the local denizens.

words.meaning: To be a sign of; indicate.
examples: A fever can denote the presence of an infection.
The red line on the map denotes the main highway.

words.meaning: The final part of a play, movie, or narrative in which the strands of the plot are drawn together and matters are explained or resolved.
examples: The movie's denouement was unexpected and shocking.
The novel's denouement left several questions unanswered.

words.meaning: To publicly declare to be wrong or evil.
examples: The president was quick to denounce the terrorist attack.
Human rights groups denounced the government's actions.

words.meaning: Stripped of its covering, possessions, or assets; made bare.
examples: The hillside was denuded of trees by the forest fire.
Years of overgrazing had left the land denuded.

words.meaning: Public condemnation of someone or something.
examples: The leader's speech was a fierce denunciation of his opponents.
The book is a powerful denunciation of social injustice.

words.meaning: To represent by a drawing, painting, or other art form.
examples: The painting depicts a scene from Greek mythology.
The novel depicts the struggles of a poor family.

words.meaning: The action or result of depicting something, especially in art.
examples: The film's depiction of the war was praised for its realism.
I was moved by the novel's depiction of love and loss.

words.meaning: To use up the supply or resources of.
examples: The war had depleted the country's financial resources.
Overfishing is depleting fish stocks in the ocean.

words.meaning: Deserving strong condemnation; shockingly bad in quality.
examples: The living conditions in the refugee camp were deplorable.
The team's performance in the last game was deplorable.

words.meaning: To feel or express strong disapproval of (something).
examples: We deplore all acts of violence.
She deplored the lack of funding for the arts.

words.meaning: To move (troops or equipment) into position for military action; to bring into effective action.
examples: The government decided to deploy troops to the border.
The company plans to deploy its new marketing strategy next month.

words.meaning: A person's behavior or manners.
examples: She had the graceful deportment of a queen.
His deportment was always professional and courteous.

words.meaning: To remove from office suddenly and forcefully.
examples: The king was deposed by a military coup.
The corrupt leader was deposed in a popular uprising.

words.meaning: The action of deposing someone, especially a monarch; the process of giving sworn evidence.
examples: The deposition of the king was followed by a period of instability.
The lawyer took a deposition from the witness before the trial.

words.meaning: Moral corruption; wickedness.
examples: The novel explores the depths of human depravity.
He was a man of great depravity who committed terrible crimes.

words.meaning: To express disapproval of.
examples: He tends to deprecate his own achievements.
The teacher deprecated the use of slang in formal essays.
